title: 112_hr4018
content: The title of the act is the "Public Safety Officers' Benefits Improvements Act of 2012." It includes benefits for certain nonprofit emergency medical service providers and miscellaneous amendments. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include the term 'hearing examiner' to encompass medical or claims examiners. Additionally, subsection (a) of section 1201 is revised to address beneficiaries if the payee indicated is living on the date of determination. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include provisions for the distribution of benefits to the survivors of public safety officers. This includes prioritizing surviving spouses, children, and designated individuals in the absence of a spouse or child. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 now includes provisions for distributing benefits to survivors of public safety officers. Benefits are prioritized for surviving spouses, children, designated individuals, and parents in equal shares if no other qualifying individuals are identified. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 provides benefits to survivors of public safety officers, prioritizing spouses, children, designated individuals, and parents in equal shares. If no other qualifying individuals are identified, benefits go to the surviving individual who would qualify as a 'child' under section 1204. Amendments to the USA PATRIOT ACT of 2001 expand the scope of officers involved in anti-terrorism efforts. Additionally, technical amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS; DETERMINATIONS; APPEALS. The Public Safety Officers Benefits under the Office of Justice Programs are amended to change decisions to determinations and make improvements as per the Public Safety Officers' Benefits Improvements Act of 2012. The USA PATRIOT ACT of 2001 specifies that payments under section 611 require a Bureau determination based on legal facts. References to section 1202 are modified, and certifications can serve as evidence. The Public Safety Officers' Benefits Improvements Act of 2012 requires appeals of Bureau determinations to be filed within 90 days of notice. Regulations apply to pending and future matters. The effective date for the regulations regarding appeals of Bureau determinations under the Public Safety Officers' Benefits Improvements Act of 2012 is specified in Section 4. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on the date of enactment and apply to pending matters before the Bureau of Justice Assistance.
